Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Social World of Homeless Youth in Mexico City.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The homeless youth of Mexico City are sometimes called street children or chav@s de la calle. They live in the sewers, wash windshields at busy intersections, or solicit money from metro riders. Their numbers are difficult to enumerate, but scholars have estimated that there are between 14,000 and 20,000 youth living and working on the streets of Mexico City. A serious problem in Mexico City, homeless youth are part of a larger, global phenomenon. UNICEF has estimated there are as many as 150 million children and adolescents living on the streets worldwide?the majority in megacities of the developing world. This project is one of the first in-depth studies of the social lives of homeless youth. The findings have the potential to inform policy and aid provision for homeless and at risk youth that live in cities across the developing world.

Street youth are a ubiquitous feature of cities in the developing world. These cities are characterized by widespread informality as the majority of households have at least one member working in unregulated income-generating activities and many live in informal or self-help housing. Scholars have examined various aspects of informality in these cities but have largely overlooked the millions of street youth who are a unique component of informality in these cities. An understanding of these settings is incomplete without an investigation of the social worlds of such youth. Through participant observation, semi-structured interviews, life-history interviews, and archival research this project will offer a holistic understanding of the lives of these youth, how they interpret their situation, the complex culture that the youth create on the street, and how they contribute to life in the larger city. By filling a gap in the literature, this project adds to the sociological understanding of social dynamics that occur in cities of the developing world and offers the information necessary to create more effective interventions and programming to better serve the population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported dissertation research to understand the social worlds of homeless youth in Mexico City. Though difficult to enumerate, it is estimated that there are millions of youth living and or working on the street worldwide, the majority being found in large cities of the developing world. They are these cities’ most vulnerable residents. Despite the prevalence of these youth in cities across the world, they have been largely overlooked by sociological research focusing on economic indicators or demographic changes and even examinations of urban poverty that aggregate the population to their community or place of residence (favelas, squatters settlements, slum dwellers, etc). This project aimed to offer one of the first in-depth examinations of the lives of homeless youth in cities of the developing world by examining their lives, how they understand and interpret their situation, the culture that they create on the street, and the various ways in which they contribute to the city around them.

 

This research was conducted in three phases over the course of a 10 month period: (1) participant observation with youth and service providers, (2) semi-structured interviews with youth and service providers, and (3) life history interviews with youth and archival research with local NGO and government offices. At all three stages, the project examined the ways in which youth interact with their families of origin; their social group; and NGO and governmental service providers to map the social worlds of these homeless youth. The findings indicate that the social worlds of these youth are shaped, and in many ways determined, by the larger political and economic policies that the city adopts. The resulting ethnography sheds light on the ways in which the political, economic, and social context of Mexico City shape and determine the situation that these youth are in. This ethnography also highlights the various ways in which the youths’ interpretation of their situation and their everyday actions are a form of resistance to the social, political, and economic exclusion they face.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project advances knowledge in Sociology, Urban Studies, Latin American studies, and International Development. This project makes a unique contribution by examining the urban poor in cities of the developing world not as an aggregate group that lives in a certain type of community, but instead focusing on understanding the complexities of the lives of one group of individuals and the ways they navigate the city around them. This adds to scholarly understanding of urban poverty in the developing world and to the social dynamics that exist within these cities. Further, by focusing this project on youth this study contributes to the growing body of literature on youth agency, youth citizenship, and the role that youth play in shaping the political and social context of cities.

 

Broader Impact: The project’s findings have the potential to help service providers and organizations throughout cities of the developing world better serve at-risk and homeless youth. For example, in 2018-2019 the organization Casa Alianza, a non-profit organization in Mexico City that works homeless youth, will use the findings to create a new outreach program to better provide services to homeless youth in the city.
